# The Prospects for an International Attribution Mechanism for Cyber Operations – An Analysis of Existing Approaches

## 1. Introduction

While there is an increasing consensus that attribution in the cyber context is not entirely impossible,¹ the actual act of attributing cyber operations to a state has remained difficult. Reasons include a lack of sufficient technical capacities within the victim states to attribute the attack, national security interests barring the states from disclosing intelligence on which a potential public attribution would be based, or the reluctance of states to undermine their good relations with alleged wrongful states. To overcome these political challenges, there has recently been an increased interest within academia, civil societies and private companies in the establishment of an independent body supervising the attribution of cyber operations to states.² But also on an inter-state level, states have relatively recently undergone efforts of collective attribution, such as in the case of the NotPetya and WannaCry cyber incidents, and, most recently, the cyber operations against Georgia.³ Collective efforts have the advantage of increasing the credibility of attribution findings, and the attribution claim gains more political weight the more states join in, which in turn might have a beneficial deterrent effect on the

## 2. The European Union⁴

The EU has relatively recently taken up the challenge of building a collective cyber security mechanism across the EU.⁵ It has also realised that it needs to step up its game regarding its attribution capabilities.⁶ A significant milestone was finding consensus on creating a set of measures which the EU and its member states can resort to in the case of a cyber incident threatening the security of the Union. This set of measures was named the ‘Cyber Diplomacy Toolbox’ (for further details see below) and also addresses the question how the EU attempts to deal with the issue of attributing these cyber incidents to state or non-state actors.⁷ Before addressing these measures, however, it is important to note how the EU defines ‘attribution’.

According to an early draft version of the European External Action Service, attribution is defined as ‘the practice of assigning responsibility for malicious cyber activity to a specific actor or sponsor’.⁸ Regarding the fact that no specific reference is made to a state actor, this definition seems to imply that the EU regards ‘attribution’ in a broader sense than it is understood under the ILC Articles on Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts (ILC Articles).⁹ Moreover, the EU is keen to note that attribution is a ‘sovereign political

## 2.1. The EU Cyber Diplomacy Toolbox

The EU has adopted the Cyber Diplomacy Toolbox in June 2017.¹¹ The Toolbox describes a set of measures with which the EU can respond to so-called ‘malicious’ cyber activities¹² under its Common Foreign and Security Policy. To be specific, the Council of the European Union¹³ decides which measures to take, based on a proposal by a Member State or the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. Measures that can be taken include démarches (i.e. diplomatic visits, usually to a state representative in charge of the dossier), public statements condemning the cyber activity, confidence-building measures, political dialogues or even restrictive measures (these will be addressed in a separate point below).¹⁴

The Draft Implementing Guidelines for the Framework on a Joint EU Diplomatic Response to Malicious Cyber Activities (hereinafter: Draft Implementing Guidelines) note that in order to resort to some, but not all, measures, prior attribution of a cyber activity is required.¹⁵ They also seem to distinguish between measures that require firm attribution and those that do not (eg when contacting states whose territory may have been used to conduct a ‘malicious cyber activity’).¹⁶ What level of proof is required for a firm attribution and for any other attribution is not specified in the available documents. It is important to note that, despite the involvement of European cyber institutions to help in the process of attribution, the power to decide to attribute remains within the hands of the member states: The Council notes that the EU INTCEN, along with other competent European ‘cyber institutions’ (such as the Computer Security Incident Response Team (CSIRT) network established under Article 12 of the EU Directive on Security of Network and Information Systems (NIS Directive)¹⁹, the European Cybercrime Centre, European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA) or the Computer Emergency Response Team for the EU Institutions (CERT-EU)), ‘plays a valuable role [...] by sharing its analyses and information related to the origin of the malicious cyber activity’.²⁰ Thus, institutions such as INTCEN are there to facilitate rather than make the decision to attribute a certain activity to a specific actor. This may entail collecting and assessing information received by member states, third states or collected on its own, followed by an analysis of the received and/or collected information. This analysis may, for example, contain a conclusion that the cyber activity, based on the available information, is with a high likelihood attributable to state X or Y. Member states may then assess this information based on their ‘sovereign prerogative’ of attribution and decide whether they agree with the analysis or not.

Whether member states will have access to the information upon which INTCEN and others created their conclusions is not clear. Especially when it comes to classified information, it is highly unlikely that the information received by one member state or a third party can be shared with the rest of the member states. In this case, member states are supposed to decide whether they follow the conclusions made by these bodies without having access to the underlying information. This decision to attribute has to be taken unanimously by all member states, if taken by the EU as a whole.²¹

An additional issue is that, according to the Implementing Guidelines ‘Member States are not obliged to provide information or analysis when it [sic] considers this as contrary to the essential interests of its [sic] national security.’²² As the necessary information will usually be linked to essential interests of a state’s national security, it might be difficult to receive valuable information at all.

## 2.2. Cyber Sanctions Regime:²³

On 17 May 2019, Council Decision (CFSP) 2019/797 and Council Regulation (EU) 2019/796 concerning restrictive measures against ‘cyber attacks’ threatening the EU or its member states have entered into force.²⁴ The Decision, which initially applied until 18 May 2020,²⁵ was amended on 14 May 2020 to apply until 18 May 2021.²⁶ The Decision and the Regulation form the basis of the new ‘cyber sanctions regime’ adopted by the EU. They impose entry restrictions on, and the freezing of funds of, persons that are responsible for ‘cyber attacks’²⁷ or attempted ‘cyber attacks’, persons who provide financial, technical or material support for or are otherwise involved in ‘cyber attacks’ or attempted ‘cyber attacks’, or others associated with these persons.²⁸

For that purpose, and in line with the procedure in other sanctions regimes, an Annex to the Decision and Regulation shall contain a list of these ‘persons, entities and bodies’ whose funds shall be frozen and who shall be denied entry into the EU’s member states.²⁹ These may be added by the Council, acting in unanimity ‘upon a proposal from a member state or from the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy’.³⁰ This means that all member states will have to agree on adding certain actors to this list, but can also veto any proposal made by a member state or the High Representative. Recital 9 of the Council Decision notes that ‘[t]argeted restrictive measures should be differentiated from the attribution of responsibility for cyber-attacks to a third State. The application of targeted restrictive measures does not amount to such attribution, which is a sovereign political decision taken on a case-by-case basis. In this context, it may be noted that there is no reference in the EU legal texts that the cyber sanctions regime is only restricted to sanctioning non-state actors who have no affiliation to a state. To the contrary, it seems to have been in the EU’s interests to also be able to impose sanctions on state actors, as the Implementing Guidelines note that restrictive measures could also be used ‘[i]n the case where the malicious cyber activity is being carried out by a State, as well as in the case when a State is deemed responsible for the actions of a non-state actor that is acting under its direction or control, or if this State recognizes and adopts the behaviour of such a non-state actor as its own’.³⁵ Here, reference is clearly made to the rules of attribution enshrined in the ILC Articles and, to some extent, the language of Articles 8 and 11 ILC Articles is used.³⁶

For a state to be held responsible under international law, the act must be attributable to the state and constitute ‘a breach of an international obligation of the state.’³⁷ Thus, attribution of an act to a state alone does not lead to any consequences under the law of state responsibility. Politically, however, it is questionable how listing state-affiliated actors in the Annex – a decision taken by all EU member states in their sovereign capacity – can be done without undertaking a collective attribution through the EU. Second, if all EU member states have to unanimously decide who will be added to this list, this act of collective attribution remains in their responsibility. One might assume that the EU is reluctant, from a foreign policy perspective, to condemn an entire state for committing a ‘malicious’ cyber activity. By listing only individuals and entities instead, attribution can be avoided and (hopefully) good relations with the affiliated state can be maintained. This cautious (and inconsistent) approach indicates the EU’s reluctance to undergo collective attribution efforts.

Regarding evidentiary standards necessary for listing: According to the EU’s Sanctions Guidelines, listing proposals must contain ‘accurate, up-to-date and defendable statements of reasons’.³⁹ The reasons for listings should moreover be ‘capable of being made public’.⁴⁰ However, ‘[i]n exceptional cases, where it is considered that the reasons for the listing are not suitable for publication, because of considerations of privacy and security, the reasons will need to be addressed separately to the person, group or entity concerned.’⁴¹ In any case, the evidence must be sufficient to withstand examination by the European Court of Justice.⁴²

Whether listing certain actors under the Annex is defined as attribution or not, the EU’s cyber sanctions regime may, on the one hand, facilitate cooperative efforts to avoid impunity for ‘malicious’ cyber acts and, on the other hand, provide helpful indications what evidence states may find sufficient enough in order to publicly condemn a ‘malicious’ behaviour in cyberspace. Of course, this will only become possible as soon as someone will actually be listed in the Annex. Nevertheless, it remains to be seen whether clear conclusions may be drawn therefrom. As listing actors in the Annex needs to follow a unanimous decision, it is highly likely that the EU will only enforce measures against actors whose listings are not too harmful for the EU member states’ political interests.

In cases of cyber operations below the threshold of an armed attack, Article 4 of the Washington Treaty calls on the NATO members to ‘consult together’ if the ‘territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the Parties is threatened’.⁴⁷ Here as well, attribution is important. Article 4 thus likewise enables the sharing of intelligence especially in the context of cyber attribution.⁴⁹ At least once, NATO has arguably already joined a collective attribution initiated by the Dutch and British governments in the cyber context, condemning the Russian hacking activities against the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons in 2018.⁵⁰ There is, however, no public information available whether NATO resorted to Article 4 in this context, nor whether it considered adhering to any evidentiary standards for attributing the act to Russia.

The consultation process can, in some circumstances, lead to a joint decision or action,⁵¹ which may include condemning acts of the wrongful state (after having attributed the activity successfully). It is clear, however, that this would have to happen in consensus with all NATO allies, which could require that – especially in the context of attribution – all NATO members are equally equipped with the necessary information and capacities to make a profound decision. In sum, NATO has realised that there is a need to increase its capacities to become an effective platform of assistance and cooperation for its members to counter cyber threats (which also includes attribution). Measures such as the Cyber Defense Pledge or cooperation agreements with other organisations seem to help with capacity-building and better cooperation. However, it is evident that an institutionalised system comparable to the EU’s ‘Cyber Diplomacy Toolbox’ does not exist.

The United States will work with like-minded states to coordinate and support each other’s responses to significant malicious cyber incidents, including through intelligence sharing, buttressing of attribution claims, public statements of support for responsive actions taken, and joint imposition of consequences against malign actors’.⁵⁹

Concerning evidentiary standards, the Cyber Strategy itself does not reveal much. However, in a paper titled ‘A Guide to Cyber Attribution’, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence explains different levels of confidence (high, moderate and low) which analysts adhere to when assessing the available evidence.⁶⁰ High confidence exists when responsibility of a certain actor can be proven ‘beyond reasonable doubt with no reasonable alternative’.⁶¹ Moderate confidence is given when the evidence is clear and convincing, and low confidence is given when ‘more than half of the body of evidence points to one thing, but there are significant information gaps’.⁶² Still, the paper does not explicitly elaborate upon which level of confidence suffices in order to conduct an attribution. In case of high confidence, it will, however, most certainly be possible to undertake an attribution.

In order to bring more states on board for a collective attribution, states will have to be on similar levels regarding their capacities to attribute. Hence, similar to NATO and the EU, the US Cyber Strategy aims at building ‘international cyber capacity’ that ‘will empower international partners to implement policies and practices which allow them to be effective partners in the United States-led Cyber Deterrence Initiative’.⁶³ Further details on how capacity-building will be achieved are also not publicly available.

However, unlike mechanisms within NATO and the EU, the US Cyber Deterrence Initiative seems to allow more flexible alliances, which can differ depending on the activity to be attributed. While NATO and EU decisions are consensus-based and thus require the backing of all its member states, the US Initiative may enable the creation of ad hoc alliances.⁶⁴ This may allow the Initiative to act more swiftly in critical situations. # 5. Conclusion

To summarise, there is potential within the EU's Cyber Diplomacy Toolbox and its newly adopted sanctions regime, NATO's alliance and the US Cyber Deterrence Initiative, to tackle the 'attribution problem'. These collective mechanisms might help release the burden of attribution by one state and increase the political pressure on the alleged wrongful state, which might even perhaps deter future 'malicious' cyber incidents. However, the biggest issue for collective attribution seems to be a lack of trust between states, which, in turn, hinders them to take collective action. Without having the possibility to assess the evidence regarding attribution by other states themselves and the fact that states usually underline that there is no international obligation to share evidence,[65] states will most likely be reluctant to support attribution claims. Closely interlinked with this is the question whether common evidentiary standards might be helpful to solve this problem. In any event, states will tend to refuse to attribute if doing so could potentially harm their international relations with the alleged wrongful state. The lack of technical expertise and insecure cyber defence systems within some states compared to other technologically well-equipped states does not help with building trust either. Hence why capacity-building is crucial, also for a collective attribution effort. To conclude, although there seems to be potential within the above-mentioned mechanisms, it is questionable whether states will make use of them or remain fairly reluctant to attribute.

Concerning evidentiary standards, the Cyber Strategy itself does not reveal much. However, in a paper titled ‘A Guide to Cyber Attribution’, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence explains different levels of confidence (high, moderate and low) which analysts adhere to when assessing the available evidence. High confidence exists when responsibility of a certain actor can be proven ‘beyond reasonable doubt with no reasonable alternative’. Moderate confidence is given when the evidence is clear and convincing, and low confidence is given when ‘more than half of the body of evidence points to one thing, but there are significant information gaps’. Still, the paper does not explicitly elaborate upon which level of confidence suffices in order to conduct an attribution. In case of high confidence, it will, however, most certainly be possible to undertake an attribution.
In order to bring more states on board for a collective attribution, states will have to be on similar levels regarding their capacities to attribute. Hence, similar to NATO and the EU, the US Cyber Strategy aims at building ‘international cyber capacity’ that ‘will empower international partners to implement policies and practices which allow them to be effective partners in the United States-led Cyber Deterrence Initiative’. Further details on how capacity-building will be achieved are also not publicly available.

# 5. Conclusion
To summarise, there is potential within the EU's Cyber Diplomacy Toolbox and its newly adopted sanctions regime, NATO's alliance and the US Cyber Deterrence Initiative, to tackle the 'attribution problem'. These collective mechanisms might help release the burden of attribution by one state and increase the political pressure on the alleged wrongful state, which might even perhaps deter future 'malicious' cyber incidents. However, the biggest issue for collective attribution seems to be a lack of trust between states, which, in turn, hinders them to take collective action. Without having the possibility to assess the evidence regarding attribution by other states themselves and the fact that states usually underline that there is no international obligation to share evidence,[65] states will most likely be reluctant to support attribution claims. Closely interlinked with this is the question whether common evidentiary standards might be helpful to solve this problem. In any event, states will tend to refuse to attribute if doing so could potentially harm their international relations with the alleged wrongful state. The lack of technical expertise and insecure cyber defence systems within some states compared to other technologically well-equipped states does not help with building trust either. Hence why capacity-building is crucial, also for a collective attribution effort. To conclude, although there seems to be potential within the above-mentioned mechanisms, it is questionable whether states will make use of them or remain fairly reluctant to attribute.

# The Prospects for an International Attribution Mechanism for Cyber Operations – An Analysis of Existing Approaches
## 1. Introduction
While there is an increasing consensus that attribution in the cyber context is not entirely impossible, the actual act of attributing cyber operations to a state has remained difficult. Reasons include a lack of sufficient technical capacities within the victim states to attribute the attack, national security interests barring the states from disclosing intelligence on which a potential public attribution would be based, or the reluctance of states to undermine their good relations with alleged wrongful states. To overcome these political challenges, there has recently been an increased interest within academia, civil societies and private companies in the establishment of an independent body supervising the attribution of cyber operations to states. But also on an inter-state level, states have relatively recently undergone efforts of collective attribution, such as in the case of the NotPetya and WannaCry cyber incidents, and, most recently, the cyber operations against Georgia. The Decision and the Regulation form the basis of the new ‘cyber sanctions regime’ adopted by the EU. # 5. Conclusion To summarise, there is potential within the EU's Cyber Diplomacy Toolbox and its newly adopted sanctions regime, NATO's alliance and the US Cyber Deterrence Initiative, to tackle the 'attribution problem'. These collective mechanisms might help release the burden of attribution by one state and increase the political pressure on the alleged wrongful state, which might even perhaps deter future 'malicious' cyber incidents. However, the biggest issue for collective attribution seems to be a lack of trust between states, which, in turn, hinders them to take collective action. Without having the possibility to assess the evidence regarding attribution by other states themselves and the fact that states usually underline that there is no international obligation to share evidence,[65] states will most likely be reluctant to support attribution claims. Closely interlinked with this is the question whether common evidentiary standards might be helpful to solve this problem. In any event, states will tend to refuse to attribute if doing so could potentially harm their international relations with the alleged wrongful state. The lack of technical expertise and insecure cyber defence systems within some states compared to other technologically well-equipped states does not help with building trust either. Hence why capacity-building is crucial, also for a collective attribution effort. To conclude, although there seems to be potential within the above-mentioned mechanisms, it is questionable whether states will make use of them or remain fairly reluctant to attribute.
